titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of Lemon and Mary Hine at DC Public Library
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ryan P. Semmes.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-05-14 23:59:31 -0400.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Frederick F. Wright, a descendant of Lemon and Mary Hine, donated the collection to the DC Community Archives. The donation was originally made in 2004, with subsequent additions made in 2005 and 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of the incoming and outgoing correspondence of both Lemon and Mary Hine. The letters begin in the 1850s and continue to the late 1880s. Most of the letters are paired with their individual envelopes. There are also letters to and from their children and other descendants of the Hine family. Also in this collection are financial records, photographs, publications, articles, and invitations. The materials are divided into three series: Correspondence, Photographs, and Ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is made up, almost entirely, of the correspondence to and from Lemon and Mary Hine. There also letters to and from their children and one postcard from their descendant Richard Wright. Some correspondence contains items sent to the recipient and remained in the envelope with the letter. These items include: an 1883-dime, swatches of fabric, and locks of hair.

did.unittitle: Lt. James S. Ransom to Lemon
Richard Wright to W. L. Wright

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial records, calling cards, articles, and Lemon Hine's Last Will and Testament.

did.unittitle: The Boy's News by C. L. Hine
"A History of the City of Washington"
Last Will and Testament - Lemon Hine
Proceedings with Reference to the Death of Lemon G. Hine
Simpson and Hine Real Estate and Lumber

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of images of both Lemon and Mary Hine, as well as an image of their Washington, DC home "Prospect Hill." There is also an image encased in a frame that is decorated with the image of the Monitor and the Merrimac. The case is made of an early form of plastic, during the Victorian era. The man in the image is unidentified, though it may be Lemon Hine or a relative of his.

did.unittitle: Daguerreotype Case with image of man (possibly young Lemon G. Hine)
